newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Fears Sfr will rise due to euro unfounded - DeSilguy.
newsitem.headline: Fears Sfr will rise due to euro unfounded - DeSilguy.

text.p: Fears that the Swiss franc will appreciate sharply because of concern about the stability of Europe's single currency are unfounded, EU Commissioner Yves-Thibault de Silguy told a Swiss newspaper in an interview.

"Some people in Switzerland fear the euro will be weak and as a result the Swiss franc will become a haven for international savings with the risk that the Swiss franc will appreciate brutally," the Journal de Geneve quoted him as saying.
"This fear is unfounded. Certainly we do not live in a world where there is zero risk, but we can minimise these risks."

"How? By assuring that the conditions for the transition to the euro envisioned in the Maastricht Treaty will be applied strictly. To be attractive, the euro must be a credible, stable and strong currency," he added.
He said the euro had to be introduced in a transparent way so that the timetable and modalities were explained well.
Parities for currencies taking part will be fixed formally on January 1, 1999, he said. "But it will be necessary to give indications beforehand so that the markets can prepare themselves."
Asked about Germany's chances to join given its budget problems, de Silguy said he could not say at this stage what Germany would do, but noted Germany had taken strict measures in this regard.
On the other hand, the treaty requires countries maintain lasting convergence with economic criteria, he added.
"What is fundamental is that the reduction of public deficits continues in 1998 and beyond. In other words, it is not only a question of a decimal," he said.
